# Introduction {.unnumbered}

*This chapter is under development. Check back soon for the full content.*

## What This Chapter Will Cover

- Limitations of GDP as a measure of economic performance
- Social welfare and happiness economics
- Islamic development indices and frameworks
- Measuring poverty and well-being in Islamic context
- Environmental sustainability metrics
- The role of social justice in measuring development
- Human development and social capital metrics
- Institutional quality and governance indicators
- Case studies of alternative measurement frameworks

::: {.callout-tip title="Key Concept"}
Islamic economics proposes that economic success should be measured not merely by aggregate output but by broader indicators of human well-being, social justice, environmental sustainability, and spiritual fulfillment, recognizing that material prosperity divorced from social equity is not true development.
:::
